sentences.text: An early Presidential elections in South Korea|presidential election will be held in South Korea on 3 June 2025. Originally scheduled for 3 March 2027, the election was pushed forward following the impeachment of Yoon Suk Yeol|impeachment and removal of Yoon Suk Yeol. The date of 3 June is due to the requirement by the constitution of South Korea for an election to be held within 60 days of a permanent presidential vacancy, which has been the case since the 4 April decision of the Constitutional Court of Korea to uphold the impeachment and remove Yoon from office. Later, it was confirmed by the Government of South Korea|government that the date of the election would be set on 3 June regardless.

references.text: <ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=Rashid |first=Raphael |last2=McCurry |first2=Justin |date=14 December 2024 |title=South Korean parliament votes to impeach president |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/dec/14/south-korean-parliament-votes-to-impeach-president |access-date=14 December 2024 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20241214093643/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/dec/14/south-korean-parliament-votes-to-impeach-president |archive-date=14 December 2024 |url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/south-korea-hold-snap-presidential-election-june-3-2025-04-08/ |title=South Korea sets snap presidential election for June 3, drawing out contenders |work=Reuters |date=8 April 2025 |archive-date=9 April 2025 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250409035627/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/south-korea-hold-snap-presidential-election-june-3-2025-04-08/ |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: Since democratization and the establishment of the Sixth Republic of South Korea|Sixth Republic, this will be the ninth presidential election, the second election after a presidential impeachment, and the first held in a different year than originally scheduled.

references.text: <ref name=IFES>{{cite web|url=https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/3014/ |title=Republic of Korea: Election for President |work=IFES |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250121044811/https://www.electionguide.org/elections/id/3014/ |archive-date=21 January 2025 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Main article|Impeachment of Yoon Suk Yeol}}
Following the 2024 South Korean martial law crisis|declaration of martial law by President Yoon Suk Yeol on 3 December 2024, the National Assembly (South Korea)|National Assembly voted to impeach him on 14 December 2024, with 204 of 300 lawmakers in support. On 4 April 2025, the Constitutional Court of Korea upheld the impeachment, removing Yoon from office and vacating the presidency. Under the Constitution of South Korea|constitution, a presidential election must be held within 60 days to determine Yoon's permanent successor as the country’s 14th president. On 8 April, acting president Han Duck-soo announced that the election would be held on 3 June 2025.

sentences.text:
{{main|Presidential elections in South Korea}}
The president of South Korea is elected via a single-round First Past The Post|plurality voting system, for a term of five years. Incumbent and former presidents are ineligible to seek re-election.

references.text: <ref name=IFES/> Unlike regularly scheduled presidential elections, the winner of this election will take office immediately after the results are confirmed by the National Election Commission (South Korea)|National Election Commission, without a two-month transition period as usual.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.koreaherald.com/article/10458485 |title=Acting president discusses snap election process with NEC chief |work=The Korea Herald |date=4 April 2025 |archive-date=8 April 2025 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250408045049/https://www.koreaherald.com/article/10458485|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The National Election Commission (South Korea)|National Election Commission (NEC) opened preliminary candidate registrations on 4 April 2025, following the confirmation of Yoon's impeachment and removal. Incumbent heads of municipal governments who intend to run for president must resign from their positions by 4 May.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20250404010151315 |title=(LEAD) Acting president discusses snap election process with NEC chief |work=Yonhap News Agency |date=4 April 2025 |archive-date=8 April 2025 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20250408044736/https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20250404010151315|url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 12 April 2025, the Democratic Party announced that it would select its official nominee for president through an even split between votes by dues-paying members and a public poll that would survey one million people through two polling companies, with a final decision to be released on 27 April following a full party vote on 14 April and an online vote by its central committee on 15 April. The party primaries will be the first time that people aged 16 to 18 years old will participate since a 2022 revision in the Political Parties Act that lowered the minimum age for party membership from 18 to 16.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=12 April 2025 |last=Woo |first=Jae-yeon |title=DP to pick presidential candidate via party vote, public poll |url=https://en.yna.co.kr/view/AEN20250412002900315 |access-date=12 April 2025 |work=Yonhap |language=en }}</ref>
